titleStmt.title: Effect of Sc and Y addition on the microstructure and properties of HCP-structured high-entropy alloys

analytic.title: Effect of Sc and Y addition on the microstructure and properties of HCP-structured high-entropy alloys

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This study aimed to design and prepare the following four kinds of refractory high-entropy alloys (RHEAs): TiZrHf, TiZ-rHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY. All the four RHEAs showed a hexagonal close-packed (HCP)-based structure. Both the strength and ductility increased in the TiZrHfSc alloy compared with the TiZrHf alloy because of the addition of Sc element and the formation of a fine needle-like lamellar structure in the former. The mechanical properties of TiZrHfY and TiZrHfScY alloys decreased after the addition of Y element because of the segregation. The conductivity of TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys decreased compared with that of pure Ti, Zr, Hf, Sc, and Y elements. However, their resistivity was comparable to the traditional electrical resistivity of the alloys at room temperature because of the serious lattice distortion in the HEAs. All the four alloys showed a typical paramagnetic behavior. These characteristics make the alloys suitable for industrial applications.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Recently, researches on high-entropy alloys (HEAs) [1,2] attracted a huge attention. As a new alloy design concept that is different from the traditional binary or ternary alloys which is based on one or two major elements as their main component, all the concentrations of the elements in HEA are between 5 and 35 at.%. This new alloys design theory brings HEAs four core effects and have shown great application potential in many fields [3][4][5]. Refractory high-entropy alloys (RHEAs) are one of the basic HEA systems, which have been widely studied due to their industrial applications, especially at a high temperature [6].

RHEAs are generally composed of refractory elements, such as Ti, Zr, Hf, W, Mo, Nb, and Ta, etc [7]. They have many excellent properties, such as high strength [8], wear resistance, oxidation resistance [9], etc. These interesting properties make RHEAs potentially at high temperature like turbine blade or armor-piercing.

Most HEAs have mainly body-centered cubic (BCC) or face-centered cubic (FCC) structure [10] or the composite structure of BCC and FCC. Only a few HEAs with a hexagonal close-packed (HCP)-structure have been reported. They show some outstanding performance such as magnetic property [11], thermal stability, and electrocatalytic activity [12]. Many reported that HEAs with the HCP structure consist of rare earth elements [13][14][15][16][17][18] because the similar atomic sizes and crystal structure of rare earth elements can easily form isomorphous solid solutions. However, rare earth elements have some well-known drawbacks such as deliquesce and oxidation. A few HCP-structured HEAs include non-rare earth elements [12,[19][20][21]. This study aimed to prepare three HCP-structured RHEAs by adding Sc and Y elements into TiZrHf alloy, because Sc and Y element may enhance the mechanical and physical properties [14,22]. In this work, the influence of Sc and Y elements on the microstructure, mechanical, and physical properties of these alloys was investigated.

div.head: Materials and methods
div.p: The purity of the raw materials (Ti, Zr, Hf, Sc, and Y) was more than 99.99 wt.%. All the alloys were melted by vacuum arc melting, remelted at least six times for homogenization, and solidified in a water-cooled copper hearth. Then, the vacuum chamber was evacuated to 3 × 10 -3 Pa and backfilled to 0.05 Pa with high-purity Ar gas. The crystal structures of the alloys were identified using the Shimadzu 6000 X-ray diffractometer (XRD). The range of scanning angle (2θ) was from 20° to 100°, and the scanning speed was 4°/min. The microstructure and phase composition of the alloys were analyzed using a Zeiss supra 55 scanning electron microscope (SEM) equipped with an energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS). Vickers hardness measurement was conducted using the MH-50 hardness tester under a load of 500 g for 15 s. The mechanical properties were measured using the DNS-100 uniaxial compression tester based on the ASTM E9-89a standard. The samples were cylindrical with 5 mm diameter and 10 mm height. The strain rate was 1 × 10 -3 s -1 . The conductivity was tested using the SIGMASCOPE SMP350 conductivity tester at room temperature. The unit of conductivity is %ICAS which set the conductivity of standard copper as 100%ICAS (about 5.8 × 10 7 S m -1 ). The magnetization curves were measured using the JDM-13T vibrating sample magnetometer. and c/a = 1.58. After the addition of elements Sc and Y, the diffraction peaks shifted to a lower 2θ degree because Sc and Y elements had larger atomic radii causing lattice expansion and may be the substitution or creation of defects in the crystal structure which led to the conversion of charge state of the component elements [23][24][25]. The TiZrHfSc alloy comprised dual HCP (HCP1 + HCP2) phases. The addition of Sc element led the formation of dual solution structure [26][27][28]. The values of the lattice constants of TiZrHfSc alloy were a = 3.1976 Å, c = 5.0455 Å, and c/a = 1.58, and a = 3.0849 Å, c = 4.7979 Å, and c/a = 1.56 for HCP1 and HCP2 phases, respectively. An electride phase with a structure of α(Y) (space group of P63/mmc) was observed with the addition of element Y. The TiZrHfY alloy mainly comprised an HCP phase and a small number of electride phase. The values of lattice constants of the HCP phase in the TiZ-rHfY alloy were almost the same as those of the HCP1 phase in the TiZrHfSc alloy, and the values of lattice constants of the α(Y) electride phase were a = 3.6471 Å, c = 5.7285 Å, and c/a = 1.57. The TiZrHfScY alloy mainly comprised dual HCP phases and a small number of αin(Y) electride phase. The values of lattice constants of the two HCP phases in the TiZrHfScY alloy were almost the same as those of the HCP1 and HCP2 phases in the TiZrHfSc alloy, and the values of lattice constants of the electride phase were almost the same as those of the electride phase in the TiZrHfY alloy. The HCP-structured TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHf-ScY alloys formed because all the composition elements had the same structure and similar characteristics inherited by TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys.

div.head: Results and discussion
div.p: Figure 2 shows the SEM images of TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys. The TiZrHf alloy exhibited a typical single-HCP structure. The TiZrHfSc alloy exhibited a needle-like dual-phase structure. The composition (Table 1) of the needle-like phase (denoted by HCP1) was near-equiatomic with slightly less amount of Sc element, and the phase between the HCP1 phase (denoted by HCP2) was rich in Sc and Ti. The reason for the difference in HCP1 and HCP2 compositions was supposed to be the melting points of Sc and Ti elements, which were lower than those of Zr and Hf. Thus, parts of Sc and Ti were pushed out of the matrix phase during the solidification process. The volume fraction of the two phases was about 93% and 7% for HCP1 and HCP2 phases, respectively. The TiZrHfY alloy exhibited a dendrite structure, with the interdendrite section being Y-rich (over 90 at%) electride phase (denoted by E). This was because the chemical mixing enthalpies between Y and other elements were higher than those of other atom pairs. Furthermore, the radius of the Y element was much larger than those of Ti, Zr, and Hf elements. Thus, only a small amount of Y (15.79 at.%) melted into the matrix phase, and the electride phase contained more than 90 at.% of Y. The volume fraction of the two phases was about 84.8% and Fig. 1 XRD patterns of TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys 15.2% for the matrix and electride phases, respectively. The TiZrHfScY alloy comprised a dual HCP structure and an electride phase. The composition of the two HCP phases in TiZrHfScY was very close to that of the TiZrHfSc alloy, and almost no Y element was detected. On the contrary, almost no Ti, Zr, or Hf elements were detected in the electride phase. According to the Sc-Y binary phase diagram, Sc and Y were mutually soluble and formed an α (Y) electride phase. This phenomenon indicated a similarity in the structure of the electride phase of TiZrHfScY and TiZrHfY alloys, which matched with the results of the XRD patterns.

Table 2 and Fig. 3 show the mechanical properties of TiZ-rHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys. The addition of elements Sc and Y led to the increase in hardness, which should be attributed to the solid solution strengthening effect and grain refinement. The TiZrHfSc alloy exhibited the best mechanical properties among all the four alloys. This might be related to the fine lamellar structure consisting of alternating dual HCP phases. After adding element Y, the hard electride phase formed at the grain boundary, which decreased the strength and ductility of TiZrHfY and TiZrHfScY alloys.

Table 3 shows the conductivity of TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys and their component elements. The conductivity of TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys was found to be lower than that of the pure metals. This was because the HEAs with serious lattice distortion led to electron scattering and decreased the conductivity. Among the alloys, the TiZrHfSc alloy has the lowest electrical conductivity, because reducing the average grain size reduces the electrical conductivity and increases the resistivity [29][30][31]. Similarly, the TiZrHfY alloy showed the highest electrical conductivity because the TiZrHfY alloy had a large grain size and electride phase with high conductivity.

Table 4 shows the resistivity of TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZ-rHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys and some common electrical resistance alloys at room temperature. It shows that the resistivity of TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys was comparable to that of traditional electrical resistivity alloys at room temperature, making TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys suitable for applications as electrical resistance alloys.

Figure 4 shows the magnetization curves of TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys. All the alloys exhibited a typical paramagnetic behavior. The specific saturation magnetizations could not be reached under the magnetic field intensity of 20,000 Oe. The coercive forces were 48. 8, 38.6, 31.4, and 47.4 Oe for TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys, respectively. The paramagnetic behavior might be due to the paramagnetic characteristics of all the elements of these alloys. What noteworthy is that based on the research of S.V. Trukhanov et al., TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys also maybe the state of spin glass, that need further research in the future [33][34][35]. Such a result provided the alloys to be potential in application of magnetics.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this study, four HCP-structured RHEAs, TiZrHf, TiZ-rHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY, were designed and prepared. Their structure, morphology, and properties were also systematically investigated. TiZrHf, TiZrHfSc, TiZrHfY, and TiZrHfScY alloys all had an HCP-based structure, showed low conductivity but high resistivity because of the serious lattice distortion and exhibited typical paramagnetic behavior due to the paramagnetic characteristics of the components. Addition of Sc led to the formation of a dual HCP structure, while addition of Y caused the formation of a α (Y)-like electride phase. The mechanical properties increased with the addition of element Sc because of the formation of a fine needle-like lamellar dual HCP structure.
After the addition of Y, the mechanical properties decreased because of the segregation of Y.
